column21:
It works fine for normal scores.  I use the same filename transformation (but using .glog instead of .gtex), so if kpathsea allows write to the .gtex file, it should allow write to the .glog file.
Snippets, on the other hand, pose a problem.  We use os.tmpname() to get a filename for writing the gabc from the snippet.  LuaTeX allows this, and the "read anything" typical permission for kpathsea will allow these to be read.  The current implementation (in this pull request) also uses os.tmpname() to get a filename for the log file.  However, the kpathsea inside the gregorio executable will reject a write to this file.
Should I disable the logging when using snippets?

column20:
This includes full fusion support and covers the open items of #898 and its duplicate #972.
Note: I based this off of #1028, so merging this will merge that as well.  This is because I was forgot to change my branch when I started work.  If #128 is to be rejected, I will rebase these changes.
Note 2: While I was coverage testing this change, I found a bug when passing a filename with no extension to gregorio, which I fixed.
I got somewhat confused during implementation, so any help testing with new and interesting combinations would be appreciated.  I have updated the tests to my satisfaction.
If this is found satisfactory, please merge it.

column21:
For those developing custom fonts, the following changes are necessary:
Glyph renames:

OriscusCavumHole to AscendensOriscusCavumHole
OriscusCavum to AscendensOriscusCavum
osbase to AscendensOriscusLineBLBR
SalicusOriscus to AscendensOriscusLineBLTR
OriscusLineBL to AscendensOriscusLineBL
OriscusLineTR to AscendensOriscusLineTR
Oriscus to AscendensOriscus
OriscusCavumReversusHole to DescendensOriscusCavumHole
OriscusCavumReversus to DescendensOriscusCavum
OriscusReversusLineBL to DescendensOriscusLineBL
odbase to DescendensOriscusLineBR
OriscusReversusLineTLBR to DescendensOriscusLineTLBR
OriscusReversusLineTL to DescendensOriscusLineTL
OriscusReversus to DescendensOriscus

New glyphs (should be self-explanatory):

AscendensOriscusLineBR
AscendensOriscusLineTLBR
AscendensOriscusLineTLTR
AscendensOriscusLineTL
DescendensOriscusLineBLBR
DescendensOriscusLineBLTR
DescendensOriscusLineTLTR
DescendensOriscusLineTR

column20:
These updates to the Mac and Windows installers (and uninstallers) get them to reflect the texmf structure that was implemented in install-gtex.sh at the suggestion of the TeXLive people.
This also addresses #1081 by having removing the *.sty files from their old location before installing.  The removal instructions are structures to also get rid of the parmesan font files.

column13: Add support for hn and hp pitches to nabc.
column20:

Shall I submit this against develop or release-4.2?

This PR cherry-picks just the packaging and TL2016 changes from 4.2.  It's designed to be completely compatible with the 4.1.1 binary so that this can be uploaded to CTAN and create a fully working installation in TL2016 without requiring the TeXLive people to upload and rebuild the binaries.
Proper testing requires you to install the 4.1.1 binary (i.e. do a full install from the v4.1.1 tag) and then use install-gtex.sh to install just the GregorioTeX files from the tip of this PR (use make ctan to build all the necessary files).  You also, naturally, need to be on the matching branch in gregorio-test.

column21:
There are a handful of tests which do not currently pass under TL2016 after these changes.  However, these can be made to pass by the following work arounds:

To solve the Undefined color issue, modify gregoriotex.sty to remove the optional argument [named] from the \color command in \gresetlinecolor.
Instead of using the geometry package to change to a4paper, use the document class option instead (about 18 tests need this change).

With these two changes, all tests pass.  The second is a temporary change that will no longer be needed once the geometry package gets updated.  The first should be in the same boat, but there's been no confirmation that the xcolor package will be updated.  Since I can get around it with a simple change in our own package, should I make that change?

column20:

column21:
For workaround 1, besides working around the Undefined color issue, what other effects does it have?  I'm inclined to let the xcolor folks fix it, but you know more about these things than I do.
For workaround 2, since the change is in the test rather than in gregorio, I think we can just make them if this is not fixed quickly enough.

column20:
This PR cherry-picks just the packaging and TL2016 changes from 4.2.  It's designed to be completely compatible with the 4.1.1 binary so that this can be uploaded to CTAN and create a fully working installation in TL2016 without requiring the TeXLive people to upload and rebuild the binaries.
Proper testing requires you to install the 4.1.1 binary (i.e. do a full install from the v4.1.1 tag) and then use install-gtex.sh to install just the GregorioTeX files from the tip of this PR (use make ctan to build all the necessary files).  You also, naturally, need to be on the matching branch in gregorio-test.
column21:
For workaround 1, besides working around the Undefined color issue, what other effects does it have?

Well, since the \color command no longer specifies the named pseudo model, one should be able to use any color expression that xcolor recognizes instead of just colors which have previously been defined with \definecolor.  I had previously forced the use of the two step process (define a color name and then use it) in order to distinguish keep color definition problems separate from GregorioTeX problems.  I suppose, then, that this bug is showing that the exact opposite is happening.

column21: The xcolor author got in touch today and sent me a potential fixed version of xcolor.sty.  I'm double checking it, but it appears to be working.  I thus expect the xcolor fix to appear in TeXLive 2016 and we won't need to use that workaround.

column21:
In order to use this feature for a font, you need to add a flattened oriscus key (set to true) to the json configuration of the font.  See fonts/greciliae.json.
The following glyphs need to be added to the base font:

DescendensOriscusFlattened
AscendensOriscusFlattened
DescendensOriscusFlatTop
DescendensOriscusFlatBottom
AscendensOriscusFlatTop
AscendensOriscusFlatBottom
DescendensOriscusLineTLFlatBottom
DescendensOriscusLineBLFlatBottom
DescendensOriscusLineTRFlatTop
DescendensOriscusLineBRFlatTop
AscendensOriscusLineTLFlatTop
AscendensOriscusLineBLFlatTop
AscendensOriscusLineTRFlatBottom
AscendensOriscusLineBRFlatBottom

The names should be fairly self-explanatory; the new tag at the end is:

Flattened - flattened on both top and bottom
FlatTop - flattened on top
FlatBottom - flattened on the bottom

column20:
First of all, please allow me to express my gratitude to your wonderful work of Gregorio!
It has been a godsend to me and to the communities in the past few years.
After a yearlong break from Gregorio, and failing to get gregorio (2.3-1) to work on Debian "unstable" yesterday, I began trying my hands on refreshing the Debian package.  I am so happy to find Gregorio alive and well, and already at version 4.1.2!
What a coincidence!  It was about the same time that TeX Live 2016 (pre-test) entered into Debian "unstable" and it finally dawned on me that the Debian texlive-binaries and texlive-music packages already contain gregorio and gregoriotex respectively.  So, a separate gregorio package might not be needed any more, but perhaps we still need it for cutting-edge versions.  :-)
Anyhow, this pull request contains some updates to the Debian packaging in the debian/ directory.
A diversion (using dpkg-divert) is probably needed for /usr/bin/gregorio to override the same executable in Debian's texlive-binaries (TeX Live 2016) before the package is fit for upload to Debian "unstable".  But, oh well, I will work on it some other day.
Last but not least, thank you so much for bringing Gregorian chant to life!
God bless you all!

column13: Update debian packaging for the "release-4.2" branch
column20:
As discussed in PR #1104, updates to debian/ shall go into the newer release-4.2 branch, hence this new pull request.  :-)
Note that a few more changes need to go in before this can be used for uploading to Debian archive, especially the need add diversion to /usr/bin/gregorio so that newer gregorio packages can override /usr/bin/gregorio in the TeX Live 2016 texlive-binaries package which has just entered Debian sid (unstable) distribution.

References:

https://www.debian.org/doc/debian-policy/ap-pkg-diversions.html
https://wiki.debian.org/Adding%20and%20removing%20diversions
Other yet-to-add change may include update debian/changelog, though probably unnecessary if the user is using debian/build-deb.sh, which adds its own debian/changelog entry on the fly anyway.


Speaking of which, debian/build-deb.sh fails to complete on the latest Debian sid (unstable) with TeX Live 2016 (pre-test?) while trying to build GregorioRef.pdf, stopping at the following error:
! LaTeX Error: Option clash for package xcolor.

See the LaTeX manual or LaTeX Companion for explanation.
Type  H <return>  for immediate help.
 ...                                              

l.42 \definecolor
               {lightgray}{gray}{0.9}
 406 words of node memory still in use:
   2 hlist, 1 rule, 1 dir, 5 glue, 4 attribute, 50 glue_spec, 4 attribute_list,
 2 write, 1 pdf_colorstack nodes
   avail lists: 2:13,3:2,4:2,5:2,7:3,8:1,9:2
!  ==> Fatal error occurred, no output PDF file produced!
Transcript written on GregorioRef.log.

which Akira Kakuto reported in http://www.tug.org/pipermail/tex-live/2016-April/038140.html.  Should we add
\RequirePackage{luatex85}
\RequirePackage[pdftex]{xcolor,graphicx}
as Akira suggested, or should we just wait xcolor is updated?
Many thanks!

column21: I can confirm a full set of tests passing.
I wonder if it might just be better to issue a warning or an error if \sc is not defined?
That would be more in line with what we do for \GreUnderline.  However, we would then need to modify the defaults styling for modes, which currently use \sc (and thus raise an Undefined macro error).
Do you think it would be too incoherent to have that default be different in PlainTeX ?
It would mean that mode numbers are lowercase roman numerals by default.  Personally I think that looks odd, but it wouldn't be terribly incoherent.
How about using roman-majuscule as the default for the mode number system in plain TeX, then?
That makes some sense.  I'll see what I can do about implementing that.
Changes implemented.  No tests change.  Does anyone think I need to add tests related to this?
Probably a single test with a mode header is good enough, but I think a test is a good idea.
GregorioRef should be updated for this change, where it describes the default mode stye and where it describes the mode number system.
Simple tests added.  Let me know if that's not enough.
I would add a gabc with mode header to those tests, exercising the difference in mode number system.
Done.
Looks good.

column20: Fixes #1107.  For some reasons placing a \relax at the end of a \raise but before the corresponding box causes the box to not be printed when luatex-ja is being used.  These \relax commands are not strictly necessary as the immediately subsequent \copy command is clearly not part of a distance and thus the LuaTeX engine has no problem detecting the end of the argument to \raise.  By eliminating them we can avoid this problem.

Thinking about it more, I believe we must be also measuring the maximum height of the alt text for inter-staff spacing, with different baselines for alt text and nabc neumes I bet we also need to measure separately the maximum heights of the alt text vs. maximum height of nabc neumes and use the corresponding baseline for those.  Or is that not the case?
As for the copy'n'paste, I think only the \gre@typesetnabcabovelines macro is large enough that it would be perhaps useful to use just one macro with an extra argument instead.

column21: In fact, in an ideal world, the second argument of \gre@hyphen would not be ignored in the case of hyphens added by Lua at the and of a line, it would be enddifference+width of (custos+space)... column21:
It looks like we'll need three:

a short bracket for typical cases where the extrema are both on a space
a long bracket for typical cases where the extrema are both on a line
the current size bracket for cases where one extremum is on a space and one is on a line (but shifted up or down accordingly); this case would also handle weird cases below and above the staff.

This is turning out to be a bit complex, so it may take me some time.

column13: Copyright notices and installation manifests for documentation
column20:
An attempt to fix #1188.
This works around the font loader issue, allowing the document to be built under TeX Live 2016.
However, doing it this way causes a segfault under (Gentoo's packaged version of) TeX Live 2015 unless the luatex font cache is cleared between runs of lualatex or if I \input the Dominican font table before the "normal" font table.  Since this doesn't happen under 2016, the bug is obviously fixed.
Is it good enough to abandon building the document under 2015, knowing that we build it anyway for distribution?  If so, then I think this is ready for review/merge.
Edit: this pull request now only adds the copyright notices and corrects the installation manifests.
column21:
An attempt to fix #1188.
This works around the font loader issue, allowing the document to be built under TeX Live 2016.
However, doing it this way causes a segfault under (Gentoo's packaged version of) TeX Live 2015 unless the luatex font cache is cleared between runs of lualatex or if I \input the Dominican font table before the "normal" font table.  Since this doesn't happen under 2016, the bug is obviously fixed.
Is it good enough to abandon building the document under 2015, knowing that we build it anyway for distribution?  If so, then I think this is ready for review/merge.
Edit: this pull request now only adds the copyright notices and corrects the installation manifests.

column21: Hmmm, I realize I wasn't clear in my initial comment, for instance in #1190 (comment) what I call a "clef change" is not really typing the clef, it's just instructing GregorioTeX to change the clef at the beginning of lines... Basically, the idea is that when a z is present in the area of a clef change, we don't make a discretionary with the different case (line breaking here or not), we directly typeset the relevant case. For instance the output of (z0::c4z) in GregorioTeX would be the same as the one (::z) plus the instruction to change the clef at the beginning of lines. Do you see what I mean?

column13: Reach the translation glyph node by traverse_id()
column20:
LuaTeX-ja prepends custom whatsit nodes to store e.g. text direction,
breaking hard-coded paths like startnode.head.next.head.next.head
in the center_translation() function.
This patch uses node.travese_id() to find our desired nodes instead.
Fixes #1180

column21:
@eroux Thank you for your review.  I am sorry that I had been very busy and still haven't found the time too follow up, especially in providing test cases in the gregorio-tests repository.
@rpspringuel Thank you so much for merging this pull request.  Unfortunately, I encountered a bug Saturday afternoon when I tried to change the Chinese font used in the translation, using \setmainjfont from luatexja-fontspec, lualatex crashed with this error:
! error:  (node lib): lua <node> expected, not an object with type nil

It crashed here:
  local trans_width = node.dimensions(glyphnode)
because glyphnode becomes nil with certain fonts, for reasons that still befuddles me.  (I know too little about TeX.)  Anyhow, my patch has wrongly assumed that the translation text would be enclosed in the glyph node directly within the hbox, as in vlist { hlist { glyph }}.  It turns out that, with some CJK fonts, the glyph node got wrapped into one deeper level, as in vlist { hlist { hlist { glyph } } }.
"Good fonts" that work: "Adobe Ming Std", "Adobe Song Std", "AR PL UKai TW", "AR PL UMing TW", where a dump_nodes() would show this:
Module gregoriotex Info: node hlist [2] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node whatsit [8] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node rule [3] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node glyph [256] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node glue [13] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node rule [3] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node glyph [256] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..penalty=10000 {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node glue [0] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node glue [0] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node hlist [0] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node glue [0] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node glue [0] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: --end dump-- on input line 63

"Bad fonts" that would crash: STZhongSong, Fandol, cwTeXKai, HanWangMingBold etc.
Module gregoriotex Info: node hlist [2] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node whatsit [8] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node hlist [0] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node glue [13] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node hlist [0] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..penalty=10000 {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node glue [0] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node glue [0] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node hlist [0] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node glue [0] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: ..node glue [0] {1} on input line 63
Module gregoriotex Info: --end dump-- on input line 63

So, my quick fix is to check for nil right after the local glyphnode = get_first_node_by_id(glyph, hlistnode.head) line:
  if glyphnode == nil then
      glyphnode = get_first_node_by_id(hlist, hlistnode.head)
  end
Though probably it shouldn't be called a glyphnode any more.  This, fortunately, fixes the crash.  For example, cwTeXKai and Fandol works perfectly after this patch.
However, with STZhongSong and HanWangMingBold, there are the occasional translation text that are not quite centered but somehow shifted to the right.  But that is a relatively minor issue that shouldn't hold up 4.1.5.
So, @rpspringuel, would you like me to make a new pull request adding the check for nil?  Or would you like to do this yourself (and probably with a better fix)?  Please let me know.  Many thanks!
(I will be at the computer this morning standing by.  I will also try to upload my test files somewhere if you would like to take a look at them.)
Thanks again!

column13: Reach the translation glyph node by traverse_id()
column20:
LuaTeX-ja prepends custom whatsit nodes to store e.g. text direction,
breaking hard-coded paths like startnode.head.next.head.next.head
in the center_translation() function.
This patch uses node.travese_id() to find our desired nodes instead.
Fixes #1180
column21:
Oops, I see that I am too late (4.1.5 is out, yay!)  No worries.  Maybe for 4.1.6 then.  I will make another pull request when I make progress (i.e. when the alignment is correct for all fonts.)
Thank you all!

column20:
This PR does two things:

The system-setup scripts are modified to account for multiple versions of gregorio residing on the same system (which happens when you upgrade gregorio in a TeXLive2016 installation).  The scripts not only show the locations of all versions of each file, but should also grab the version numbers out of them (where appropriate) so that you can see which is where.  This finishes #1197
PlainTeX package loading order is modified to work around the bug noticed as a result of #1199.  The bug in color/graphicx has been reported, but this means we don't have to wait for the fix for our tests to be working again.

It should be noted that the modified Windows batch file makes use of where which means that it is no longer 100% compatible with XP.  Microsoft claims that XP knows where, but based on other information I've found the 32-bit version of XP doesn't actually know the command (though it can be added).  Given that XP is now 2+ years past end of life, I'm comfortable dropping full support for it at this point.

column21:
Hi @rpspringuel, thank you so much for merging #1201.  But, if it is at all possible, please "stop the press!" and wait just a little bit longer (say an hour or two?) before you actually release 4.1.5: I found a bug in my code, in that when \setmainjfont is used to set the Chinese/Japanese font, the user is likely to run into this crash:
! error:  (node lib): lua <node> expected, not an object with type nil

For example, "Adobe Ming Std" and "AR PL UKai TW" work fine, but STZhongSong, Fandol, cwTeXKai etc. would crash... for some reasons, with some fonts, the glyph node isn't found within the hbox, but instead one level deeper.
I have a 3-line patch, not perfect, but at least no more crashing.
I will write more at #1180 or #1201.
Thanks again!

column21: \grenabccharno has been in from the beginning of gregoriotex-nabc.tex, but it was defined by \newcommand, so it wasn't caught before.  The best person to ask would be @jakubjelinek, but it simply calls (in Lua) gregoriotex.parse_nabc.  Looking at this function, it prints the nabc glyphs for the nabc string passed as #1. #2 is the font name used as an index into nabc glyph tables, and #3 is a scaling factor that is currently hard-coded to 1 (presumably for some future configurability?)

column21: Given that description, I think this function needs to be moved out of the user namespace (where it currently resides) and into the internal namespace (i.e. be renamed to \gre@nabccharno). column20:
Fixes #1007.
Nothing has been done for the divisio minima or the virgula since those bar shapes, being on the top line, do not affect the space calculation.
I added a test for the specific case and updated the expectations (mostly gabc-to-gtex) which change appropriately.
Please review and merge if satisfactory.

On Nov 8, 2016, at 12:01 PM, Henry So notifications@github.com wrote:
@henryso commented on this pull request.
In tex/gregoriotex-main.tex:

@@ -444,6 +444,11 @@
\gre@debugmsg{ifdim}{ manualinitialwidth = 0pt}%
\ifdim\gre@space@dimen@manualinitialwidth=0 pt\relax%
\global\gre@dimen@initialwidth=\wd\gre@box@initial %


 \ifdim\gre@dimen@initialwidth<\gre@space@dimen@minimalinitialwidth\relax%



   \gre@style@initial%

I copied that from the manualinitialwidth code immediately below. I'm pretty sure it's there to handle relative dimensions like em since space@dimen macros are text.  Therefore, I don't think the style lines should be removed.

column21:
I'm not sure uninstall-gtex.sh should be executable.  Wouldn't it be better to instruct users to run bash uninstall-gtex.sh rather than accidentally running uninstall-gtex.sh because it's executable?  The executable bit in a zip file is also not completely portable (though it works with pretty much everything except the original pkzip).
--no-uninstall is a vestige; it really depends on setting GENERATE_UNINSTALL (i.e., GENERATE_UNINSTALL=false ./install-gtex.sh).  At this point we have two options.  I can either make --no-uninstall work, which would require more sophisticated argument parsing, or take that out of the usage and leave it to those reading the comments at the top of file to understand how it works.  I favor the latter.

column20:

column21:
I've no problem with the instructing the users to use bash uninstall-gtex.sh but in that case isn't the shebang redundant?  It's my understanding that the shebang is there to indicate which program to use to run an executable and thus would not be necessary in a script which is not meant to be an executable.
Removing --no-uninstall  from the usage statements sounds fine.

column20:
Fixes #1223.

column21: Yes, your understanding of the shebang is correct; it is not necessary, but it hints to some editors (like mine) that the file is a bash script.  However, I can accomplish that other ways, so I will remove the line and replace it with a comment.

column21: Actually, I don't expect anyone to spot the problems in the code (though if anyone can, that would be nice).  Rather I'm looking for people to examine the test results and visually decide if they are "right" or not.  I can spot the "problems" because I've been looking at the results with the barspacing and notespacing markers, but they're fairly small and so I'm not sure that someone approaching an unmarked score with fresh eyes will even be able to spot them.  If no one sees them, then I think it's reasonable to accept this as is and wait for some use case to crop up in which those small problems become unacceptably large before spending more time trying to quash them.

column20:
This adds the script to check the syllabation of scores. It has proven extremely useful in the italian Antiphonale Monasticum projects and allowed to spot many errors, so I advise everyone to use it!
It's quick and dirty and could certainly be improved (some gabc constructions can confuse it, but it's extremely rare), feel free to improve it!

column21: Okay, I see.  I guess what confused me is that the default hyphenation pattern file name is specifically hyph_la_liturgical.dic which comes from hyphen-la.  I wonder, then, if there should be a default value for the pattern file.  I understand it's convenient when one uses a particular pattern file a lot, but might it not be better to have no explicit default and allow users to create wrapper scripts if they want that functionality?

column13: Updated spaces from the Italian Antiphonale Project.
column20:
Fixes #1182.
@eroux Please double check that I pulled in all the changes.  I didn't set change the eolhyphen or custosalteration settings, and I left the emergency stretch set as \the\emergencystretch.  You'll also see that I changed various interwordspacetext values from the old ex-dimensioned values (which seemed weird given ex is a relative vertical height) to the cm-dimensioned values for similar spaces from the Italian Antiphonale Project.
I added a CHANGELOG.md entry, but no UPGRADE.md because I can't see a way that a user can easily "opt out" of these changes.
See the corresponding test pull request for notes on the tests.
Please review and merge if satisfactory.

Well, I think it's necessary to document it somewhere, and enven though the gabc part of the pdf is not really the best place, at least it's somewhere. When someone will compile a gabc documentation, he'll take this as a reference (among other things), and so he'll document [nocustos], so I think it's helpful to put it there, even though it won't be very useful right now... What do you think?
About mixed, something like
foo... (::[nocustos]) line break
bar... (::) line break with custos
foo... (a[nocustos]b) line break between a and b
bar... (ab) same
foo... (a[nocustos]) (b)
bar... (a) (b)

column13: Fix various significant letter typesetting issues:
column20:
grelaon uses position 5 for significant letters (inside neume), which must be
always present in the font, use highest priority for those
typesetting has been wrong when using toSlsa6lti8, the tironian letter which
was supposed to be below the torculus actually ended up below the augete
the order of letters when at the same position matters, we would typeset
tslst2lsc2 as tslsc2lst2 because only the latter is present in the font
grelaon font now has also two glyphs with 3 significant letters
column21:

the order of letters when at the same position matters, we would typeset

column20: As it turns out, the script was causing TeXShop to misbehave, even to the point of not opening.  After some emailing back and forth with Richard Koch (the maker of TeXShop) its been worked out that support opening and editing Gregorio related files will appear built-in to the next release of TeXShop itself.  What Ive done, therefore, is removed the problematic portions of the configuration script.  All it really does now is copy the engine into the appropriate directory.
column21: As it turns out, the script was causing TeXShop to misbehave, even to the point of not opening.  After some emailing back and forth with Richard Koch (the maker of TeXShop) its been worked out that support opening and editing Gregorio related files will appear built-in to the next release of TeXShop itself.  What Ive done, therefore, is removed the problematic portions of the configuration script.  All it really does now is copy the engine into the appropriate directory.

column20:
I realized that the supplemental fonts were ending up in a few places they shouldn't in the releases.  These modifications should remove them.
Note: Two of the modifications make the assumption that the gregorio and granapadano fonts have not been built and thus we only need concern ourselves with their source files (gregorio-base.sfd and granapadano-base.sfd).  I could code a check for the ttf files and remove them if they are there but haven't done so at this point because I don't think it's entirely necessary.  Does anyone think otherwise?

column20:
I realized that the supplemental fonts were ending up in a few places they shouldn't in the releases.  These modifications should remove them.
Note: Two of the modifications make the assumption that the gregorio and granapadano fonts have not been built and thus we only need concern ourselves with their source files (gregorio-base.sfd and granapadano-base.sfd).  I could code a check for the ttf files and remove them if they are there but haven't done so at this point because I don't think it's entirely necessary.  Does anyone think otherwise?
column21:
I don't think it's necessary because the same effect can be had simply by doing the builds for a release in the right order and from a clean repository.  I've already altered my release building script (which automates most of the steps to creating a full set of release files) to reflect that order and the first step in that script has always been make maintainer-clean, so this is a problem I'm not going to run into again.
I guess the better question, then, is "Is this sufficient?"  It certainly works so long as I'm the only one running the release build cycle.  Do we want to count on that?

column21: I think it's sufficient as long as the release build order is documented, perhaps in the wiki.

column21: I'll take a look later today, but one thing that occurs to me right off the bat is that we've been really sloppy about debug message keywords thus far, simply adding whatever we felt we needed as we worked on a specific problem.  I think it might be a good idea to start documenting the debug message keywords, i.e. a list of what words have been used and a short description of what sort of messages they correspond to (much like what @henryso just did in #1326 when directing us to this PR).  Perhaps a section in Command_Index_internal?

column20:
I started this while working on 1285 and found it so useful that I went whole hog and formalized it and applied it to all the internal functions.  It could be applied to Gregorio or user name space functions as well, but I'm less sure that there's a gain from that.
Nominally at least, tests aren't supposed to change as a result of this PR, but #1331 was found as a result of applying this, so that needs to be resolved before this is merged.

column21: I only traced the internal macros because the calling of them tends to be more hidden than the calling of user or Gregorio namespace ones, which actually appear in source files (or gtex ones).  I could add tracing to all macros if that would be more useful.

column20:
TeXShop 3.77 has a new feature (by my request) that allows one to add an additional parameter to TeX files which can then be exploited by the engine files.  For these engines Ive used the parameter to add a folder (specified by the parameter) to the input paths.
Ive also added a Plain TeX version of the engine.

column13: Added --enable-texlive flag and support for a suffix-less executable.
column20:
Fixes #1292.
Because we laid so much groundwork for this, it took less time to implement than I thought, but I need help testing it in anything other than Linux.
I'm also not sure how to document this.  This is not a user-visible change, so it doesn't belong in CHANGELOG.md, and no entry is needed in UPGRADE.md.  As mentioned in #1292, it basically allows the build files to be set up for TeX Live.
Note: I changed @rpspringuel's code a bit because (1) redirection to /dev/null will likely not work under Windows, (2) to make executable check lazy, so it's only done (once per run) if needed, and (3) to try to find the suffixed executable before the suffix-less executable.
Please review and give suggestions, or merge if this is good enough.

Are you using something lower than that?

column21:
Looking at the sample, I think that's more of a typographic difference rather than a variant/style within the typographic style.  I think it's best to just have that be a font thing and don't see a need to put another set of glyphs in the current font.  I could put this other style in the gregorio font, if you think that OK.
However this does bring up an issue of the difficulty in redefining bar glyphs.  The code currently uses font substitution to select bar glyphs based on number of staff lines.  This makes it impossible to change the bar glyphs via glyph substitution.  The solution is not as simple as an additional level of indirection because sized bars are defined as variant glyphs.  I think the solution will have to be an additional level of indirection plus a renaming of bar glyphs, but I need to think about this a bit more.

column20:
Fixes #1360.
Please review and merge if satisfactory.
column21:
Looking at the sample, I think that's more of a typographic difference rather than a variant/style within the typographic style. I think it's best to just have that be a font thing and don't see a need to put another set of glyphs in the current font. I could put this other style in the gregorio font, if you think that OK.

That sounds good.

However this does bring up an issue of the difficulty in redefining bar glyphs. The code currently uses font substitution to select bar glyphs based on number of staff lines. This makes it impossible to change the bar glyphs via glyph substitution. The solution is not as simple as an additional level of indirection because sized bars are defined as variant glyphs. I think the solution will have to be an additional level of indirection plus a renaming of bar glyphs, but I need to think about this a bit more.

Would it be possible to use a sort of offset system?  I.e. set things up so that the 2, 3, 4, and 5 line variants of the bar lines always have the same relative location to each other in the code points.  We would then add a particular offset which corresponds to the number of lines to a base code point which corresponds to the kind of bar line.  Changing to a variant bar line, therefore, would be a matter of changing just the base code point (which should be fairly similar to the way our variant glyph system works for other glyphs), while changing the number of lines would be changing the offset.

column21: I think it's more straightforward to bring in all the sizes of bars into \GreCP variables (e.g., \GreCPVirgulaTwo, \GreCPVirgulaThree, \GreCPVirgulaFour, \GreCPVirgulaFive, etc.) and have the code that switches number of lines set the variables to be used for the given score (e.g., set \GreCPVirgula to \GreCPVirgulaFour for a 4-line staff).  Then the user could map these glyphs directly, even with asterisks if the names in the alternate font are the same.  This is my current thought, but I have not dived into the code to see how feasible this implementation is.

column13: Script for uploading package to CTAN
column20:
This adds a script which makes use of ctan-o-mat (a script which comes with TeXLive) to upload the package to CTAN.  Naturally the CTAN package file must be built before it can be uploaded, so we check for it before trying to upload, but do not build it if it is not there.
The script attempts to scrape as much information as possible from the repository in creating the upload, but the user should always supply the text of the release message when invoking the script (as the first argument).  This can be skipped, but it is not recommended so the script asks for confirmation before letting that happen.
Finally, if it is needed, a second message can be added which is directed to the CTAN upload managers.  This is always the second argument of the script and can be left blank without a problem.
I've tested everything except the actual upload step, but can't test that until we have something to upload to CTAN.  We should probably hold off on merging this PR until we have a chance to test the script fully (i.e. whenever 5.1.1 is released).
Feel free to pick my coding apart and make suggestions for improvement, however.

I tried and ran into problems with the changelog because it's a muli-line substitution.  sed complained about unescaped newlines.  PERL was the only solution I could make work there, and just used it for the others for consistency.  If you know how to make that substitution then I'd be glad to make the change.


Br. Samuel, OSB
(R. Padraic Springuel)
PAX  

 On Mar 16, 2018, at 8:55 AM, Henry So ***@***.***> wrote:

 @henryso commented on this pull request.

 In ctan_upload.sh:

 > +if [[ ! -e "gregoriotex.ctan.zip" ]]; then
 +  echo "CTAN release not created"
 +  echo "Please run \"make ctan\" and try again"
 +  exit 1
 +fi
 +
 +VERSION=`./VersionManager.py --get-current`
 +FILE_VERSION=`echo $VERSION | sed s:[.]:_:g`
 +pkgfile="gregorio-$FILE_VERSION.pkg"
 +
 +# copy config file
 +cp "ctan-o-mat.config" "gregorio-$FILE_VERSION.pkg"
 +
 +# changelog entry
 +changes=$(awk "/$VERSION/ {p=1; next}; /[0-9]+\.[0-9]+\.[0-9]+/ {p=0}; p" "CHANGELOG.md")
 +perl -s -i -0777 -pe 's/<<<CHANGELOG>>>/$to/' -- -to="$changes" "$pkgfile"
 Why not do this stuff with sed, so perl is not required?

Finally, if it is needed, a second message can be added which is directed to the CTAN upload managers.  This is always the second argument of the script and can be left blank without a problem.
I've tested everything except the actual upload step, but can't test that until we have something to upload to CTAN.  We should probably hold off on merging this PR until we have a chance to test the script fully (i.e. whenever 5.1.1 is released).
Feel free to pick my coding apart and make suggestions for improvement, however.

column21: When files are first created, they sometimes are given a single copyright year instead of a range (i.e. (C) 2018 instead of (C) 2018-2018).  You probably ought to check for that and append a hyphen and the current year instead of simply replacing the final year.  That should be as simple as looking for the hyphen in a line identified as containing a copyright and doing re.sub(fileyear, fileyear+'-'+CURRENTYEAR, line) instead of re.sub(fileyear, CURRENTYEAR, line)

column21:
Thanks for looking into all that.  I didn't have time to do much more than generate the list when I was looking earlier.
greextra.sfd has had some pretty major modifications over the years (in particular gresym.sfd was merged into it in 2015) so I'm going to say that this one should have the Copyright updated.  It also looks like the current copyright in the file might be due to a copy/paste error anyway, as it refers to greciliae.  The font first appeared when mensural et al. clefs and custos were added in 2010.
@eroux, can you clarify the original history of this font?  In particular, did Matthew Spencer have anything to do with those original glyphs (i.e. only the font name in the copyright statement is in error) or was the whole statement accidently copied from greciliae?
gabc-syntax.plist: looking at the history, this one hasn't been changed since it's original commit so probably leave it off.

column20:
Obviously the biggest issue with this PR is that it creates a compatibility problem with TeX Live 2017.  Earlier versions will work, as will TeX Live 2018.  Is it a good idea to have that kind of hole in the support?  The change is not needed to make TeX Live 2018 work, its just a bit cleaner code.
In any event, I don't think this should be merged until after TeX Live 2018 is released (sometime this summer).

column20:
This is a rewrite of the Scribus tool to make it simpler.  Instead of Scribus writing a lua script and calling texlua on it to write two files (the gabc and tex file) and then run lualatex on the result, I make use of the filecontents package to make the writing of the gabc file part of what calling lualatex on the tex file does.  Thus Scribus writes the tex file and calls lualatex on it directly.
Tested as working on both Ubuntu and macOS using Scribus 1.4.6.

column20:
When looking for files, GregorioTeX will now employ kpse.find_file if it does not find the file is not in the expected location.  This allows for TEXINPUTS to specify paths to scores and addresses the bug part of #1395.
The one thing I'm not sure about is that I make no attempt to strip off directories before doing the kpse based search.  Should I?

column21: Just discovered an interesting quirk: kpse.find_file appears capable of traversing directories with spaces in the name while the \input statement which actually reads in the gtex file is not.  This results in an interesting bug where the code finds a gtex file which is ready for importing, but cannot actually read it in.  Not sure if this is simply something that needs documenting or some sort of code fix.

column20:
The use of filecontents rather than filecontents* was leading to a comment header that made it impossible for Gregorio to find the gabc headers in the temporary score file.
Some of the indenting (which makes the file more human readable) was leading to errors in the formatting of the created files because they are processed in a way which handles whitespace differently from XML.
This is not a file which is uploaded to CTAN so I've made this PR against develop (for inclusion in the next enhancement release).  However, since the file is not uploaded to CTAN, this commit could be cherry-picked if the next release turns out to be a bugfix rather than an enhancement.  Some rewriting of the CHANGELOG would be needed in that event.
See #1457.

column20:
Fixes #1461
Staff line thickness scales with the size of the staff, but was not being set in gsp-default.tex.  As a result, whenever the default spacings were loaded and the staff size wasn't currently set to the default, the line thickness would change.  This change puts the setting of the staff line thickness into gsp-default so that it will scale as expected.

column20: The uninstall script stub is installed fairly early in the process, before many of the installed files are put into place (it's populated as the files are installed).  Since the presence of this script is considered a block to future installations (barring the use of the AUTO_UNINSTALL variable) this makes life difficult when the installation fails part-way through.  Since a partial installation won't work anyway, this change makes use of the uninstall script stub to remove the partial install and then removes the stub itself, clearing the way for a clean installation after the problem causing the failure has been fixed.

column20: Corrected interaction issues between text styles and ligatures.  The LaTeX commands like \textit insert italics correction, preventing ligatures being formed between their arguments if two occur sequentially.  On the other hand the switches like \itshape do not.  Since gregorio breaks up syllables around the vowel and then applies the formating commands to each part, this behavior showed up.  We switch to using the switches to avoid this (except for underlining, for which a switch does not exist).  We also fix this for color tags by loading luacolor which changes how the \color tag is implemented to allow ligatures to span groups.  See #1444.

column20:
Addresses underlying cause of #1460
This PR moves gsp-default.tex to be an internal file.  This allows for us to version check it to make sure we're loading one which properly defines all needed distances and penalties.  As part of this \grecreatedim is moved to the internal namespace as \gre@createdim.
gsp-sample.tex is now provided in the doc folder as an example space configuration.  Right now it's simply a duplicate of gsp-default.tex except for the following:

It has no version check (version checking is only for internal files)
It uses \grechangedim (an User macro) instead of \gre@createdim (an internal macro)
The comments have been edited to make them slightly more user friendly (please double check these)

column21:
That'll make it harder for people to reload the defaults after changing to a custom space.  As is \greloadspaceconf{default} will reload the default spacing configurations, if we change the name, then that won't work.
Oh... That does make me realize something though, because rescaling is handled within \grechangedim (which is not used in gsp-default.tex) we're going to run into a scaling problem when reloading the defaults if the current staff size is not 17.  I'm going to need to add some special handling for loading the defaults to account for that.
Now that I think about it, I guess that makes it relatively easy to change the name.  If there's already some special handling of the defaults, that special handling can be extended to the file name too.

column21: This looks OK to merge to me.  In your opinion, how "breaking" is this to people in the middle of a project?  In other words, if you are in the middle of the project, would you want to be cautious when updating?  If so, then this is probably left out of CTAN until a release with a proper UPGRADE.md entry or at least better warning.

column20: Note: this includes #1467 because it would conflict with it otherwise.  This is only a spacing change (#1261), and so could be included in ctan, but given the above, and that it's really such a minor issue, I've pulled it against develop instead.
column21:
If the project contains only scores at size 17 (the default) or are using their own spacing configurations, then the change isn't breaking at all.  For any project which contains scores at other sizes but still use the default spacings (just scaled) then this will make a difference.  I think the difference is an improvement, but others might disagree.  If you look at some of the ancillary tests which changed you can get a sense for how much of a difference the change makes.
This is already against develop, and thus as is won't go to CTAN until next year.  To push it to CTAN earlier would require me to redo the PR (and not include #1467).  I can add an UPGRADE.md entry for it.

column20: Use KOMA-Script article class to achieve the intended appearance with fewer additional packages. Improve font loading with Libertinus package.
column21: The resulting appearance is very similar  this only aims to simplify the setup, to allow new users to focus on Gregorio itself. KOMA-Script has defaults that achieve what the various added packages are intended to do here, but with a much more comprehensive manual that makes it easier for new users to modify. For comparison, see the original and modified versions.

column20: Use KOMA-Script article class to achieve the intended appearance with fewer additional packages. Improve font loading with Libertinus package.
column21:
Personally, I don't consider the KOMA-Script classes to be simplifications.  They're more all-inclusive and put more thing "under the hood" so to speak, which can lead to less appearing in the project file (especially when the defaults are acceptable) but one of the reasons I like using LaTeX is because I like the way it exposes things.  The granularity of packages is a feature, not a bug, for the way I work.
I realize this isn't for everyone, so I too don't have really strong feelings about this.  Perhaps the best compromise would be to have multiple examples which model different possibilities.

column20: Use KOMA-Script article class to achieve the intended appearance with fewer additional packages. Improve font loading with Libertinus package.
column21:
In teaching LaTeX to new users, I have found that many tend to see a long list of packages that they don't understand, and blindly copy them into every new document, because it vaguely works, but without knowing why.
For this reason, I've found that KOMA-Script is a better place for new people to start, since it has a manual covering most of what one would want when getting started. For advanced users, there's no question that bare-bones packages are often desirable.
I think you have already achieve the aim of giving different models on the examples page.

column20: Use KOMA-Script article class to achieve the intended appearance with fewer additional packages. Improve font loading with Libertinus package.
column21: Are the changes I made to this acceptable, or would you prefer to stick with the article class? (Again, my aim here is to make the file as simple as possible to make it clear what Gregorio itself needs.)

column20: Use KOMA-Script article class to achieve the intended appearance with fewer additional packages. Improve font loading with Libertinus package.

Thanks!

column20:
With some significant refactoring and bug-fixing along the way, this PR is about supporting initials of an arbitrary number of lines explicitly.
Right now I've got two "modes" for doing so:

manual - each line which wraps the initial must be manually ended in the gabc (z or Z).  This is the way 2-line initials are currently supported and so is set as the default.
semi-manual - the last line that wraps the initial must be manually ended in the gabc.  Should be slightly easier to use, but can lead to the initial overlapping full width staves when the manual line ending is far too early.

I'd like to make something which is fully automatic, but have yet to come up with a good way of tracking the automatic line endings.  I've identified a point in the post_linebreak function where the line numbers are increasing as expected, but I'm not sure how, or even if, I can resize the lines on the lua side.  Hence, I'm posting this here for some feedback.
Note: This still needs some documentation work and so is not ready for merge.

column21:
Hmm... Another thing I noticed that still needs fixing:
Right now the placement of the initial is based purely on the height of the first line (multiplied by the appropriate number of lines to lower the initial when the initial is wrapped by more than one line).  Since the subsequent lines could be slightly taller or shorter, this means that 2 or more line initials may be slightly higher or lower than they ought to be (in the test case, they're all higher).  Ideally I should access the actual heights of the second (and later) lines when they wrap the initial.

column21: I've done some more research on this and am rapidly coming to the conclusion that implementing the fully automatic multi-line initial may require changing how the lines are drawn: going from using \localleftbox to having post_linebreak do it.  That's a bit beyond my current skills, but I'll keep plugging away at it.

With some significant refactoring and bug-fixing along the way, this PR is about supporting initials of an arbitrary number of lines explicitly.
Right now I've got two "modes" for doing so:

manual - each line which wraps the initial must be manually ended in the gabc (z or Z).  This is the way 2-line initials are currently supported and so is set as the default.
semi-manual - the last line that wraps the initial must be manually ended in the gabc.  Should be slightly easier to use, but can lead to the initial overlapping full width staves when the manual line ending is far too early.

I'd like to make something which is fully automatic, but have yet to come up with a good way of tracking the automatic line endings.  I've identified a point in the post_linebreak function where the line numbers are increasing as expected, but I'm not sure how, or even if, I can resize the lines on the lua side.  Hence, I'm posting this here for some feedback.
Note: This still needs some documentation work and so is not ready for merge.
column21:
I'm working on accounting for actual line heights and came across a "magic number" in the \gre@calculate@additionalspaces: 15750 sp (it also appears in \gre@calculate@glyphraisevalue).
Based on how it's being used, it appears to be like it's supposed to be the amount of additional space to add for excessively high/low elements.  Does any one know why this calculation isn't using noteadditionalspacelinestext?  @henryso @eroux?  The value is not exactly the same (once scaled for the default 17 staff size) but is really close (0.1436cm vs the 0.14413cm in notesadditionalspacelinestext).

column20:
With some significant refactoring and bug-fixing along the way, this PR is about supporting initials of an arbitrary number of lines explicitly.
Right now I've got two "modes" for doing so:

manual - each line which wraps the initial must be manually ended in the gabc (z or Z).  This is the way 2-line initials are currently supported and so is set as the default.
semi-manual - the last line that wraps the initial must be manually ended in the gabc.  Should be slightly easier to use, but can lead to the initial overlapping full width staves when the manual line ending is far too early.

I'd like to make something which is fully automatic, but have yet to come up with a good way of tracking the automatic line endings.  I've identified a point in the post_linebreak function where the line numbers are increasing as expected, but I'm not sure how, or even if, I can resize the lines on the lua side.  Hence, I'm posting this here for some feedback.
Note: This still needs some documentation work and so is not ready for merge.
column21: After some painstaking traces through the git history concerning this magic number and noteadditionalspacelinestext it appears that the magic number was introduced when additional space above the lines for high notes was implemented while noteadditionalspacelinestext was introduced when additional space below the lines for low notes was implemented (the name being a variation of spacelinestext: the nominal distance between the lines and the lyrics baseline).  It would thus appear that this magic number should be replaced by a new distance noteadditionalspaceabovelines (the name being a variation of spaceabovelines: the nominal distance above the lines).  If there are no objections to this solution, I will implement it as part of this PR.

column21: Getting the line height adjustments for variable line heights right is proving much harder than expected.  @henryso, can you look at the code in my most recent commit (39d9496) and see if I'm doing anything blatantly wrong.  Things aren't lining up as I would expect them to and I'm trying to figure out if that's do to my not understanding the way the line height information is stored and used, or if it's because there's something more subtle in the way the spacing around lines works.
Please pull this against the ctan branch.  We don't apply patches directly to master.

column20:
Fixing problem identified by user: https://groups.google.com/g/gregorio-users/c/u3LmnGYnhwU
We were reusing a register to save and restore the value for the \hyphenpenalty.  The register was used both at the whole score level and around a No Line Break Area.  As a result, when we attempted to restore the \hyphenpenalty at the end of the score, we ended up setting it to what it was just before the No Line Break Area, not what it was before the score.
This PR does some refactoring of all registers used to save values for restoration so as to not just fix this one problem, but hopefully make it harder to repeat the same mistake in the future.
There's also a couple of minor fixes here and there which were discovered while reviewing the documentation for this fix.
Note: the problems identified in #1495 still exist in this PR.

column20:
There is no Latin vowel definitions in gregorio-vowels.dat by default because they are built into the binary itself.  The user can, however, define their own alternative, so it is conceivable that there might be.  We thus print a little extra information when were falling back to the internal Latin vowel definitions so that the user isn't confused by the "Could not find" message.
Fixes #1470.
No testing changes.

column21:
Can you post a copy of the tex file that Scribus creates?  I'm need to see what the filecontents* environment contents end up being to make more educated guesses as to how to make this work.

Is there a reason that gregorio does not ignore white space not contained between : and ; preceding the %% in a .gabc file?

The reason is mostly that we never thought about that possibility.  We always assumed that gabc file writing would be done by hand.  Unfortunately, scribus, while using an XML file to define a rendering frame, doesn't really understand the indentation of an XML file and thus sometimes thinks XML indentation should be part of the target file it's supposed to create.  Further, we actually need to write two files (the gabc and the tex file) while the render frame tool only expects to need to write one.  Thus we have to design the tex file to create the second automatically in a way that is compatible both with how Scribus interprets the XML and with how filecontents interprets its contents.  Getting such indirection right is complicated (especially since none of the developers actively use Scribus and thus testing requires one of us to relearn it each time we run into problems).
@henryso, Could the lexer be modified to ignore spaces in header names?

WithBlankLineFirst.zip
If </preamble> is down on its own line in 900_gregorio.xml, then here are the two situations:
Given the default input to the Scribus render frame editor, these are gabc, gtex, and glog files that are generated.

WithBlankLinePreambleOwnLine.zip

column20:
There were several "magic distances" still in the code.  All of these distances are related to calibrating things to the fonts and so should not be user editable.  However, having those numbers scattered through the codebase is harder to maintain (if you change one, you have to figure out which of the others also needs to change, by how much, and where they all are), so based on relationships between the numbers, I've reduced them to 6 named dimensions which are then used as needed in the various calculations.
Fixes #1521.

column21:
One question on this remains:
Right now we have noteadditionalspacelinestext which is the amount of space added per level of really low note and is approximately ((\gre@dimen@interstafflinedistancebase + \gre@dimen@stafflinethicknessbase) / 2 ) (the vertical distance between notes a half-step apart).  Should we replace this distance with the formula or is there a reason why when adding space between the notes and the lyrics, one would want to add something other than the distance actually required by the low note position?

column21: It should be noted that currently in the code ((\gre@dimen@interstafflinedistancebase + \gre@dimen@stafflinethicknessbase) / 2 ) is used for high notes above the staff.  For consistencies sake, if noteadditionalspacelinestext it to be retained, then we should do something similar for the above staff notes.

If were going to preserve the ability to manually set the space for low notes, should we add the ability to do so for high notes?  If so, should the user be able to independently decide whether to use the manual or automatic setting for low and high notes (requiring two switches with two positions each), or does it suffice to have there be a single manual vs automatic setting?
